trial_identification.studytitle: Outcome of Juvenile Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) reconstruction with Live Donor Allograft
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Outcome of Juvenile Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) reconstruction with Live Donor Allograft

interventions.interventions: The aim of this research is to assess the 2 year clinical outcome of live donor hamstring tendon allograft in juvenile ACL reconstruction. Assessment will include knee stability, subjective outcomes, return to sport and reinjury at 1 and 2 years after surgery with standardised, reliable and validated assessment tools.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Clinical and subjective outcome as assessed by the International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) Evaluation, KT1000 arthrometer, Lysholm Knee Score, effusion, and kneeling pain

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Skeletal alignment at maturity assessed via radiographs and Tanner scores

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Patients age 16 years or less at time of surgery 2. Patients undergoing ACL reconstruction with the use of live donor hamstring tendon graft by Dr Pinczewski or Dr Roe 3. Surgery to be performed at the Mater Hospital, Sydney 4. Patients willing to participate in a research program 5. Patients willing and able to attend Mater clinic for assessments
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patients unwilling or unable to attend Mater clinic for assessments

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study will prospectively follow group of up to 100 patients who undergo ACL reconstruction under the age of 17 years with the use of a live donor allograft.
